item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Delmore Schwartz
item.description:
"Time is the school in which we learn, Time is the fire in which we burn.
(Calmly We Walk Through This April's Day)" -- Delmore Schwartz

item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Franz Kafka
item.description: "A First Sign of the Beginning of Understanding is the Wish to Die." -- Franz Kafka

item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Franz Kafka
item.description: "Don't bend; don't water it down; don't try to make it logical; don't edit your own soul according to the fashion. Rather, follow your most intense obsessions mercilessly." -- Franz Kafka

item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Ben Tanzer
item.description: "The bigger you feel things, the more curious you are; and the more problems you want to solve and not actually run from, the better everything is, even the things you already love." -- Ben Tanzer

item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Delmore Schwartz
item.description:
"O your life, your lonely life What have you ever done with it, And done with the great gift of consciousness? What will you ever do before Death's knife Provides the answer ultimate and appropriate?
As I for my part felt in my heart as one who falls, Falls in a parachute, falls endlessly, and feels the vast Draft of the abyss sucking him down and down, An endlessly helplessly falling and appalled clown:
This is the way the night passes by, this Is the overnight endless trip to the famous unfathomable abyss." -- Delmore Schwartz

item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Todd Michael Cox
item.description: "Nature's probably my greatest inspiration. Everything I need is found in nature, it compels me to create and care. If you can't find what you're looking for in wild places or the eyes of wild creatures, it probably doesn't exist." -- Todd Michael Cox

item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Friedrich Nietzsche
item.description: "A casual stroll through the lunatic asylum shows that faith does not prove anything." -- Friedrich Nietzsche

item.title: Ginnetta add a quote by Jarod Kintz
item.description: "I think the key indicator for wealth is not good grades, work ethic, or IQ. I believe it's relationships. Ask yourself two questions: How many people do I know, and how much ransom money could I get for each one?" -- Jarod Kintz
